awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Documentation of Diidxa za (ZAI) spatial language
awd_abstract_narration:
Doctoral student Randi Tucker will conduct an in-depth study of landscape features in the endangered language Diidxa za (also known as Isthmus Zapotec), a language spoken in Oaxaca, Mexico.  Tucker's study will result in a database of land and water form terminology and a documentation of linguistic and cognitive practices of reference to geographic-scale and small-scale space. 
Tucker's study develops a new approach in studying the intersection of geography and culture, called 'ethnophysiography'.  This approach seeks to document terms of reference for landscape forms and features, and the role of landscape in culture.  This type of documentation can tell us more about how humans interact with their surroundings with respect to factors like agricultural sustainability.
The project involves data collection in five communities to discover how the local landscape is represented in the lexicon; how route descriptions are used to explore the use of landscape entities as anchors of reference frames, and linguistic and recall data on reference frames in small-scale space.  The proposed activity will test the relative efficacy of language and the non-linguistic factors of local topography, urbanization, education, bilingualism, and literacy in shaping linguistic and non-linguistic practices of spatial reference. 
The resulting linguistic documentation will help with the emerging language revitalization efforts for the region.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported field research for Randi Moore’s doctoral dissertation to document and analyze two aspects of the representation of space in Zapotec-speaking communities of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec in Oaxaca, Mexico: (i) lexical resources for the description of geographic entities such as land and water forms, and (ii) linguistic and cognitive practices of reference to geographic-scale and small-scale space. Diidxa za is unique among Zapotec varieties in that there is very little dialectal variation throughout a larger regional area (i.e. mutual intelligibility exists throughout the Isthmus, whereas outside the Isthmus it is often restricted to a few individual towns). This variety was selected for this project due to its endangered status and the uniquely varying topography in which the speaker communities are situated. Moore explored the influences of topography and demographic factors on spatial language and cognition. She collected in three communities free-lists of lexical items from the domain of local landscape, route descriptions to explore the use of landscape entities as anchors of reference frames, and linguistic and recall data on reference frames in small-scale space, along with participants’ demographic data.  

 

The description of the spatial language of Diidxa za adds significantly to the scientific record of Diidxa za in the domains of landscape terminology and spatial reference. The description of environmental features and their cultural salience contributes to the field of ethnophysiography, the study of the linguistic and cultural representation of the landscape. This project also explores the role of topography in spatial frame of reference preferences in language and cognition. This issue speaks to the Linguistic Relativity Hypothesis, which posits that language has a causal influence on cognition. This project tested the relative efficacy of language and the non-linguistic factors of local topography, urbanization, education, bilingualism, and literacy in shaping linguistic and non-linguistic practices of spatial reference, to find that community membership, more so than any other demographic factor tested, significantly contributes to variation in the type of geocentric reference frame type used.

 

Recorded data are accessible to the local speaker communities as well as the linguistic academic community via the Archive of Indigenous Languages of Latin America. These data include: (i) discourse interactions of 196 speakers making spatial descriptions of objects in small-scale space, (ii) free-lists of landscape entities from 30 speakers, and (iii) route descriptions elicited from 30 speakers. These recordings are transcribed and translated into Spanish. The project supported ongoing research interest in the language, as well as supporting community efforts to maintain and revitalize the language. Through the course of the project, native speaker community members were employed in assisting with task recruitment and transcription and translation, and received training for these activities as well.
